title: Pirate Parrot-turned-Clark the Cub adds another level of intrigue to wild-card game | Baseball
text:
The Pirates lost the face of their franchise last year, and hardly anyone noticed.
It was early in spring training when Alex Collins, who portrayed the Pirate Parrot for seven seasons, turned in his feathers to become Clark, the brand new mascot of the Chicago Cubs.
Now, it would be easy to label Collins a traitor or a turncoat. The Pirates, the club with whom his allegiances formerly lay, host the charging Cubs Wednesday in the do-or-die National League wild-card game. Collins will be in Chicago and a bear costume.
This can all be explained by a deep dive into the world of major league mascots, a society shrouded in secrecy, strange specifics and so, so little speaking. Collins was not available for comment for this story, but, hey, when was the last time a mascot talked?
In the business, the person in costume is referred to as the mascot's "best friend" or "coordinator" so as to maintain the illusion that the character is real. That's why the Pirates, too, had no comment; in their view, the parrot is the parrot even if Collins is gone.
David Raymond was the original Phillie Phanatic, first sporting the furry, green garb back in 1978. He has seen just about every shift in the mascot universe these past four decades, but he can't recall an instance of a person jumping from one mascot costume to that of a rival team.
"I can't imagine me leaving the Phillies as the Phanatic and performing for the Mets, for God's sakes," Raymond said. "Oh, boy, Mr. Met."
He was the Phanatic's "best friend" from 1978 to 1993.
Since then, Raymond created Raymond Entertainment and has become a world-class mascot trainer and adviser. He met Collins at one of his mascot boot camps and, in 2004, helped him get his first job as the mascot of the Lake Elsinore Storm, a Class A baseball team in California.
Raymond is plenty familiar with the Pirates. He has helped train most every Pirate Parrot, going all the way back to Kevin Koch, the bird's original coordinator. Koch was fired in 1985 for his involvement in baseball's cocaine scandal.
When the Pirates needed to hire a new mascot coordinator in 2007, Collins auditioned. Raymond was hired to scout talent to invite to the tryout, which had "all the anxiety that an American Idol audition could produce." It starts with a suit-and-tie interview.
"What they don't want to see is a silly, wacky, crazy employee," Raymond said. "That would be disruptive. ... Alex was a total package of a good performer and a great employee."
So why did Collins want to leave after seven seasons? Well, he's from Indianapolis, and those who know him say he grew up a Cubs fan. When the Cubs started searching for their first Clark, it was almost a no-brainer for him. Before applying, Collins called Raymond to talk it over. His choice was clear.
"If Clark happens to show up to Pittsburgh (today) with Alex inside, it might spontaneously combust," Raymond said, laughing. "We're mixing forces that we've never mixed before. You never know. This is uncharted water."
Erin Blank, the owner and president of Keystone Mascots in Brownstown, Pa., near Lancaster, spent four seasons as the Detroit Tigers mascot, Paws. When she won the job, an executive asked her, "You understand you beat out 4,000 other applicants, right?" Blank was shocked.
She also knows the life of a major league mascot isn't always easy. While some are strictly performers, she said, others are asked to run kids clubs and bring in sponsorships for the mascot. She even knew one mascot who needed to have a Class C driver's license because he was expected to move promotional items with a pallet truck.
So, when asked whether the mascot code might prohibit a performer from joining a rival club, she laughed. There are a few professional mascots out there who are fortunate enough to work for their childhood favorite team, but most are just trying to make a living.
Blank doesn't know the particulars of the Pirates and Cubs jobs, but she wouldn't wag a finger at Collins for going to the Cubs.
"Alex has done a wonderful job of helping to bring Clark into the affectionate arms of the fold without stepping on too many toes," she said.
And so the major league mascot wheel of fortune turned. When Collins became Clark, another Clark -- Clark Cairns -- became the Pirate Parrot's new best friend.
"Whoever wins," Raymond said, "I'm friends with the mascot."
